newsArray.title: Boult still wants to play for New Zealand at World Cup
keywords: Boult still wants to play for New Zealand at World Cup
creator: Reuters Reuters
newsArray.description: (Reuters) тАУ Seamer Trent Boult still wants to play for New Zealand at this yearтАЩs World Cup and tests next year despite giving up his central contract to allow him to spend more time with his family. The 33-year-old, who with Tim Southee has made up one of the worldтАЩs most feared pace attacks over [тАж]
newsArray.content: FILE PHOTO: Cricket - New Zealand Practice Session - Trent Bridge, Nottingham, Britain - June 9, 2022 New Zealand's Trent Boult during practice Action Images via Reuters/Andrew Boyers/File Photo (Reuters) тАУ Seamer Trent Boult still wants to play for New Zealand at this yearтАЩs World Cup and tests next year despite giving up his central contract to allow him to spend more time with his family. The 33-year-old, who with Tim Southee has made up one of the worldтАЩs most feared pace attacks over the last decade, has not played international cricket since negotiating a тАЬsignificantly reduced roleтАЭ with the Black Caps in August. тАЬIтАЩve still got that big desire to play for New Zealand,тАЭ Boult told Cricinfo in Jaipur, where he is playing for the Rajasthan Royals in the Indian Premier League (IPL). тАЬIt is what it is: IтАЩve made my decision. IтАЩve been lucky enough to have a 13-year career in the Black Cap and hey, IтАЩve still got a big desire to play in the World Cup as well. тАЬItтАЩs such a great tournament тАж one hundred percent, IтАЩve got that desire to be out there.тАЭ Boult was part of the squads that finished runners-up at the last two 50-overs World Cups and thought New Zealand would again be a force in India in October and November. тАЬWeтАЩre a great one-day side,тАЭ he added. тАЬWeтАЩve got some players that have travelled to India and experienced the conditions a lot, and thatтАЩs what it comes down to in World Cups. тАЬYou canтАЩt buy experience, and you canтАЩt replace players that have toured for however many years across these conditions.тАЭ Boult was snubbed for New ZealandтАЩs home test series against England earlier this year, despite the hosts losing a string of fast bowlers to injury and the first test taking place close to his Mount Maunganui home. тАЬIt felt bizarre,тАЭ he said. тАЬTest match cricket was on, a couple of kilometres down the road, and I wasnтАЩt part of it.тАЭ The pace spearhead said he hoped he had not played his last match for New Zealand in the longest format. тАЬThere are some big tests coming up next year. Australia and South Africa are due to travel to New Zealand. And test cricket is still my favourite format.тАЭ тАЬThey said that if I chose to move away from that contract, my time тАж would be limited and IтАЩm pretty sure theyтАЩve never had anyone play test cricket that isnтАЩt contracted тАУ so that probably makes it hard as well.тАЭ

newsArray.title: England cricketer Sam Billings reveals his battle with skin cancer
newsArray.description: England cricketer Sam Billings has revealed he underwent two operations to remove a malignant melanoma on his chest as he warned his fellow players about the risks of skin cancer.
newsArray.content: England cricketer Sam Billings has revealed he underwent two operations to remove a malignant melanoma on his chest as he warned his fellow players about the risks of skin cancer. Wicketkeeper Billings, 31, said his England team-mates were left shocked by his тАШgory and bloodyтАЩ six-inch scar and stitches when he removed his shirt in the changing rooms during last yearтАЩs white-ball tour of Australia. He admits he was fortunate to have the skin cancer diagnosed during a routine screening at his county, Kent, before it developed into anything worse. Billings recovered to play a full winter of cricket but is urging players at all levels of the game to make sure they apply suncream when they take the field. On that moment in the England dressing room, he told the Daily Telegraph: тАШI had completely forgotten it was there! But I still had my stitches in and it was pretty gory, still bloody and healing. I think the boys were pretty shocked. тАШIтАЩve been that classic Brit abroad. As a 22-year-old with fairer hair in Australia thinking it was worth going a bit red to end up brown. тАШAnd at home you see it all the time, it gets to 12 degrees and sunny, all the tops come off. I didnтАЩt think IтАЩd be the guy who got skin damage. I hope people see my story and think twice.тАЩ Billings almost skipped the skin cancer screening at Kent because there was a queue and he was running late for a meeting. It was only the intervention of the clubтАЩs head physio Dan George that persuaded the captain to hang around. It revealed a mole on his upper chest that needed to be removed. Billings was told he had a melanoma that was 0.6mm deep, with the threshold of 0.7mm being when things can really get serious, and was immediately refereed for an operation. тАШI could see inside my own chest, which wasnтАЩt very nice,тАЩ he said. тАШAt one point the anaesthetic didnтАЩt work well so I was in huge pain. тАШI never realised how much your chest affects everything else. Just moving my arm was extremely painful. Mentally it was definitely more challenging than physically.тАЩ In partnership with the Professional CricketersтАЩ Association and Lifejacket Skin Protection, Billings has warned club cricketers not to get sunburnt when they play. тАШWe treat it [applying suncream] like a bit of a chore because the education around it isnтАЩt as good as in countries like Australia,тАЩ he added. Billings isnтАЩt the first top-level sportsman to reveal they have suffered from skin cancer. The Germany and Bayern Munich goalkeeper Manuel Neuer revealed last year he required three operations to remove a tumour from his face. Tennis star Angelique Kerber has also suffered from the sun-induced skin condition hyperpigmentation. The lifelong condition, which can be easily treated, is caused by exposure to the sun and leads to spots or patches that look brown, black, grey, red or pink on the skin. (Daily Mail)

newsArray.title: 3 things we learnt about Zimbabwe A from day 1 of the 2nd four-dayer against the Shaheens
creator: 3-mob.com
newsArray.description: It was not good day for Zimbabwe A The post 3 things we learnt about Zimbabwe A from day 1 of the 2nd four-dayer against the Shaheens first appeared on Three Men On a Boat.
newsArray.content: Zimbabwe A had one good thing and a lot of bad things on a the first day of the Pakistan Shaheens in Mutare Sports Club. The visitors came into the match holding a 1-0 lead after winning the match in Kwekwe last week. The Shaheens won the toss and put Zimbabwe A. They were bowled out for what would have been a very disappointing 163 just after tea. The Shaheens are 115 for the loss of one wicket at stumps. Here are the three lessons we learnt Once seen as a white ball player, Tadiwanashe Marumani is showing that he has fight and grit, He scored 66 runs in a 110-run partnership with Dion Myers, which looked to have set the Zimbabweans for a good first innings score. He generally leftt well and punished the bad balls in an innings which had a strike rate of 66. What the Shaheens showed is that once one is in, you should get a big one. The Zimbabweans on the other hand seem to be comfortable with the half century and very rarely take it further. Three players had ducks meaning they added nothing to the total. The senior players in the team were absent. That Nyasha Mayavo was next highest with 17 is simply at odds with where Zimbabwe want to be. Or at least where they want to to go. The match resumes on day two at 9.15am. On this episode of the Clubhouse End Podcast, Larry Kwirirayi is joined by Stan Chioza to discuss Joylord GumbieтАЩs century against Pakistan Shaheens, Dion Myers, Selection, a quick buildup to the Qualifier, Kelis Ndhlovu and WomenтАЩs cricket development in Zimbabwe.

newsArray.title: Power-hitters raise the bar in new era of IPL run-fests
creator: Ariana News
newsArray.description: A marauding Faf du Plessis and emerging power-hitters including Rinku Singh have helped make team totals over 200 the new normal in this high-scoring edition of the Indian Premier League. The 38-year-old South African Du Plessis, captain of Royal Challengers Bangalore, leads the batting charts with 576 runs at a destructive strike rate of over [тАж] The post Power-hitters raise the bar in new era of IPL run-fests first appeared on Ariana News.
newsArray.content: The 38-year-old South African Du Plessis, captain of Royal Challengers Bangalore, leads the batting charts with 576 runs at a destructive strike rate of over 157 and 32 sixes. This season does not finish until the end of the month but it has already witnessed 30 innings totalling 200 or above. That happened on 18 occasions in the entire edition last year. Du Plessis hit 65 on Tuesday and forged a 120-run stand with Glenn Maxwell тАФ but opponents Mumbai Indians still reached the 200 target with 3.3 overs to spare, AFP reported. This season third-placed Mumbai have chased down three 200 or 200-plus totals with Suryakumar Yadav hitting half-centuries in all of them. тАЬI have no idea what a safe score is. The last four games we have seen excess of 200 has been scored,тАЭ said Mumbai skipper Rohit Sharma. тАЬMost of the teams are taking risks and it is coming off. тАЬThe batters are taking risks and 200-plus scores are being chased. тАЬThe mindset of the batters is to do something special for the team and it is coming off as well.тАЭ Players and pundits say there are a few reasons for the tall totals. IPL pitches are more batting friendly than before to encourage big-hitting and provide more entertainment. Former Australia batsman and ex-IPL coach Tom Moody says that the Kookaburra balls could have something to do with it because they are not swinging as much. The nature of Twenty20 cricket is also evolving, with a new breed of specialists. But the biggest factor behind the skyscraper scores in the IPL looks to be the new Impact Player rule. It allows a substitute and effectively adds an extra batsman or bowler to the team line-up. Lucknow Super Giants have led the high-rise war after they posted the second-highest team total since the IPL began in 2008. They made 257-5 in a 56-run victory last month against Punjab Kings, with West IndiesтАЩ Kyle Mayers and Australian all-rounder Marcus Stoinis smashing 11 boundaries each. Virat Kohli recently scored a 46-ball 55 in a losing cause for Bangalore and the superstar batsman was criticized for consuming too many deliveries. Moody called KohliтАЩs innings тАЬyesterdayтАЩs approach or last yearтАЩs approachтАЭ. тАЬNow we have an impact player, the game has changed,тАЭ the Australian, who took Sunrisers Hyderabad to the 2016 title, told ESPNCricinfo. тАЬWe already have evidence of that with the number of teams who have scored over 200, (it) is a record number of 200-plus scores of any IPL and we are not even close to the finish.тАЭ While the likes of greats Kohli and David Warner have struggled to meet the intensity, left-handed batsman Rinku has come into his own as a finisher this season. He raised the hitting stakes when he smashed five sixes in the last five balls to pull off a miracle chase for Kolkata last month. The tournament has witnessed six last-ball finishes this season and Mumbai batsman Nehal Wadhera pointed to the impact sub again. тАЬThe Impact Player rule also gives the batters a bit of freedom to play fearlessly as they know they have an extra batter in their wings,тАЭ Wadhera said. тАЬThe rule has also led to more close finishes in the IPL, which we love to watch.тАЭ

newsArray.title: PCB refuse to play Asia Cup outside Pakistan
newsArray.description: Pakistan Cricket Board (PCB) rejected the idea of playing Asia Cup outside Pakistan, as Sri Lanka Cricket Board had suggested to host the event in their country and letting Pakistan remain the official hosts. PCB suggested Asian Cricket Council (ACC) the hybrid model once again, in which it was offered that India can play their matches in UAE. Sri Lanka and Bangladesh do not have problem with the hybrid model but do not want to play matches in UAE due to hot weather. The board official told Samaa TV that PCB had written an email to the boards of Bangladesh and Sri Lanka that Asia Cup has been played in UAE in the past in the months of August and September as well. The honourary secretary of SLC Mohan De Silva has reportedly said that they have told ACC that they are against hybrid model and would be prepared to host Asia Cup in their country but nothing has been finalised yet. But Pakistan Cricket Board have stayed firm on their stance that they would boycott the event if it is held outside Pakistan.

newsArray.description: LONDON (Reuters) тАУ Skin cancer prevention should be a priority for cricketers and fans spending hours under the sun, England wicketkeeper Sam Billings has warned after suffering a scare last year. Billings underwent two operations last year to remove a malignant melanoma on his chest following a routine screening organised by his county Kent. The [тАж]
newsArray.content: FILE PHOTO: Cricket - Fifth Test - England v India - Edgbaston, Birmingham, Britain - July 1, 2022 England's Sam Billings in action Action Images via Reuters/Jason Cairnduff LONDON (Reuters) тАУ Skin cancer prevention should be a priority for cricketers and fans spending hours under the sun, England wicketkeeper Sam Billings has warned after suffering a scare last year. Billings underwent two operations last year to remove a malignant melanoma on his chest following a routine screening organised by his county Kent. The 31-year-old said his melanoma was caught just in time and that he almost missed the screening to attend a meeting. тАЬI had a melanoma that was 0.6mm (deep). The threshold of when it gets really serious is 0.7mm, so really close,тАЭ Billings told the Daily Telegraph. тАЬIf I had left that screening to go to the meeting, and waited until my next one six months down the line it could have been far, far more serious.тАЭ While searing heat and sunshine are regularly seen in Asia and Australia, Billings says conditions in Britain can be just as dangerous and that English players can be complacent. тАЬIтАЩm not just talking about the pro game. ItтАЩs club cricketers, people who watch the game,тАЭ he said. тАЬI played at LordтАЩs recently and the sun was out, even if it wasnтАЩt 25 degrees. It might only have been 18 but you can still get sunburnt. We treat it (applying suncream) like a bit of a chore, because the education around it isnтАЩt as good as in countries like Australia. тАЬIтАЩd like to see everyone in cricket working together: the sun is out, so letтАЩs protect ourselves.тАЭ

newsArray.title: Boult still wants to play for New Zealand at World Cup
keywords: Boult still wants to play for New Zealand at World Cup
creator: Reuters Reuters
newsArray.description: (Reuters) тАУ Seamer Trent Boult still wants to play for New Zealand at this yearтАЩs World Cup and tests next year despite giving up his central contract to allow him to spend more time with his family. The 33-year-old, who with Tim Southee has made up one of the worldтАЩs most feared pace attacks over [тАж]
newsArray.content: FILE PHOTO: Cricket - New Zealand Practice Session - Trent Bridge, Nottingham, Britain - June 9, 2022 New Zealand's Trent Boult during practice Action Images via Reuters/Andrew Boyers/File Photo (Reuters) тАУ Seamer Trent Boult still wants to play for New Zealand at this yearтАЩs World Cup and tests next year despite giving up his central contract to allow him to spend more time with his family. The 33-year-old, who with Tim Southee has made up one of the worldтАЩs most feared pace attacks over the last decade, has not played international cricket since negotiating a тАЬsignificantly reduced roleтАЭ with the Black Caps in August. тАЬIтАЩve still got that big desire to play for New Zealand,тАЭ Boult told Cricinfo in Jaipur, where he is playing for the Rajasthan Royals in the Indian Premier League (IPL). тАЬIt is what it is: IтАЩve made my decision. IтАЩve been lucky enough to have a 13-year career in the Black Cap and hey, IтАЩve still got a big desire to play in the World Cup as well. тАЬItтАЩs such a great tournament тАж one hundred percent, IтАЩve got that desire to be out there.тАЭ Boult was part of the squads that finished runners-up at the last two 50-overs World Cups and thought New Zealand would again be a force in India in October and November. тАЬWeтАЩre a great one-day side,тАЭ he added. тАЬWeтАЩve got some players that have travelled to India and experienced the conditions a lot, and thatтАЩs what it comes down to in World Cups. тАЬYou canтАЩt buy experience, and you canтАЩt replace players that have toured for however many years across these conditions.тАЭ Boult was snubbed for New ZealandтАЩs home test series against England earlier this year, despite the hosts losing a string of fast bowlers to injury and the first test taking place close to his Mount Maunganui home. тАЬIt felt bizarre,тАЭ he said. тАЬTest match cricket was on, a couple of kilometres down the road, and I wasnтАЩt part of it.тАЭ The pace spearhead said he hoped he had not played his last match for New Zealand in the longest format. тАЬThere are some big tests coming up next year. Australia and South Africa are due to travel to New Zealand. And test cricket is still my favourite format.тАЭ тАЬThey said that if I chose to move away from that contract, my time тАж would be limited and IтАЩm pretty sure theyтАЩve never had anyone play test cricket that isnтАЩt contracted тАУ so that probably makes it hard as well.тАЭ

newsArray.title: England cricketer Sam Billings reveals his battle with skin cancer
newsArray.description: England cricketer Sam Billings has revealed he underwent two operations to remove a malignant melanoma on his chest as he warned his fellow players about the risks of skin cancer.
newsArray.content: England cricketer Sam Billings has revealed he underwent two operations to remove a malignant melanoma on his chest as he warned his fellow players about the risks of skin cancer. Wicketkeeper Billings, 31, said his England team-mates were left shocked by his тАШgory and bloodyтАЩ six-inch scar and stitches when he removed his shirt in the changing rooms during last yearтАЩs white-ball tour of Australia. He admits he was fortunate to have the skin cancer diagnosed during a routine screening at his county, Kent, before it developed into anything worse. Billings recovered to play a full winter of cricket but is urging players at all levels of the game to make sure they apply suncream when they take the field. On that moment in the England dressing room, he told the Daily Telegraph: тАШI had completely forgotten it was there! But I still had my stitches in and it was pretty gory, still bloody and healing. I think the boys were pretty shocked. тАШIтАЩve been that classic Brit abroad. As a 22-year-old with fairer hair in Australia thinking it was worth going a bit red to end up brown. тАШAnd at home you see it all the time, it gets to 12 degrees and sunny, all the tops come off. I didnтАЩt think IтАЩd be the guy who got skin damage. I hope people see my story and think twice.тАЩ Billings almost skipped the skin cancer screening at Kent because there was a queue and he was running late for a meeting. It was only the intervention of the clubтАЩs head physio Dan George that persuaded the captain to hang around. It revealed a mole on his upper chest that needed to be removed. Billings was told he had a melanoma that was 0.6mm deep, with the threshold of 0.7mm being when things can really get serious, and was immediately refereed for an operation. тАШI could see inside my own chest, which wasnтАЩt very nice,тАЩ he said. тАШAt one point the anaesthetic didnтАЩt work well so I was in huge pain. тАШI never realised how much your chest affects everything else. Just moving my arm was extremely painful. Mentally it was definitely more challenging than physically.тАЩ In partnership with the Professional CricketersтАЩ Association and Lifejacket Skin Protection, Billings has warned club cricketers not to get sunburnt when they play. тАШWe treat it [applying suncream] like a bit of a chore because the education around it isnтАЩt as good as in countries like Australia,тАЩ he added. Billings isnтАЩt the first top-level sportsman to reveal they have suffered from skin cancer. The Germany and Bayern Munich goalkeeper Manuel Neuer revealed last year he required three operations to remove a tumour from his face. Tennis star Angelique Kerber has also suffered from the sun-induced skin condition hyperpigmentation. The lifelong condition, which can be easily treated, is caused by exposure to the sun and leads to spots or patches that look brown, black, grey, red or pink on the skin. (Daily Mail)

newsArray.title: 3 things we learnt about Zimbabwe A from day 1 of the 2nd four-dayer against the Shaheens
creator: 3-mob.com
newsArray.description: It was not good day for Zimbabwe A The post 3 things we learnt about Zimbabwe A from day 1 of the 2nd four-dayer against the Shaheens first appeared on Three Men On a Boat.
newsArray.content: Zimbabwe A had one good thing and a lot of bad things on a the first day of the Pakistan Shaheens in Mutare Sports Club. The visitors came into the match holding a 1-0 lead after winning the match in Kwekwe last week. The Shaheens won the toss and put Zimbabwe A. They were bowled out for what would have been a very disappointing 163 just after tea. The Shaheens are 115 for the loss of one wicket at stumps. Here are the three lessons we learnt Once seen as a white ball player, Tadiwanashe Marumani is showing that he has fight and grit, He scored 66 runs in a 110-run partnership with Dion Myers, which looked to have set the Zimbabweans for a good first innings score. He generally leftt well and punished the bad balls in an innings which had a strike rate of 66. What the Shaheens showed is that once one is in, you should get a big one. The Zimbabweans on the other hand seem to be comfortable with the half century and very rarely take it further. Three players had ducks meaning they added nothing to the total. The senior players in the team were absent. That Nyasha Mayavo was next highest with 17 is simply at odds with where Zimbabwe want to be. Or at least where they want to to go. The match resumes on day two at 9.15am. On this episode of the Clubhouse End Podcast, Larry Kwirirayi is joined by Stan Chioza to discuss Joylord GumbieтАЩs century against Pakistan Shaheens, Dion Myers, Selection, a quick buildup to the Qualifier, Kelis Ndhlovu and WomenтАЩs cricket development in Zimbabwe.

newsArray.title: Power-hitters raise the bar in new era of IPL run-fests
creator: Ariana News
newsArray.description: A marauding Faf du Plessis and emerging power-hitters including Rinku Singh have helped make team totals over 200 the new normal in this high-scoring edition of the Indian Premier League. The 38-year-old South African Du Plessis, captain of Royal Challengers Bangalore, leads the batting charts with 576 runs at a destructive strike rate of over [тАж] The post Power-hitters raise the bar in new era of IPL run-fests first appeared on Ariana News.
newsArray.content: The 38-year-old South African Du Plessis, captain of Royal Challengers Bangalore, leads the batting charts with 576 runs at a destructive strike rate of over 157 and 32 sixes. This season does not finish until the end of the month but it has already witnessed 30 innings totalling 200 or above. That happened on 18 occasions in the entire edition last year. Du Plessis hit 65 on Tuesday and forged a 120-run stand with Glenn Maxwell тАФ but opponents Mumbai Indians still reached the 200 target with 3.3 overs to spare, AFP reported. This season third-placed Mumbai have chased down three 200 or 200-plus totals with Suryakumar Yadav hitting half-centuries in all of them. тАЬI have no idea what a safe score is. The last four games we have seen excess of 200 has been scored,тАЭ said Mumbai skipper Rohit Sharma. тАЬMost of the teams are taking risks and it is coming off. тАЬThe batters are taking risks and 200-plus scores are being chased. тАЬThe mindset of the batters is to do something special for the team and it is coming off as well.тАЭ Players and pundits say there are a few reasons for the tall totals. IPL pitches are more batting friendly than before to encourage big-hitting and provide more entertainment. Former Australia batsman and ex-IPL coach Tom Moody says that the Kookaburra balls could have something to do with it because they are not swinging as much. The nature of Twenty20 cricket is also evolving, with a new breed of specialists. But the biggest factor behind the skyscraper scores in the IPL looks to be the new Impact Player rule. It allows a substitute and effectively adds an extra batsman or bowler to the team line-up. Lucknow Super Giants have led the high-rise war after they posted the second-highest team total since the IPL began in 2008. They made 257-5 in a 56-run victory last month against Punjab Kings, with West IndiesтАЩ Kyle Mayers and Australian all-rounder Marcus Stoinis smashing 11 boundaries each. Virat Kohli recently scored a 46-ball 55 in a losing cause for Bangalore and the superstar batsman was criticized for consuming too many deliveries. Moody called KohliтАЩs innings тАЬyesterdayтАЩs approach or last yearтАЩs approachтАЭ. тАЬNow we have an impact player, the game has changed,тАЭ the Australian, who took Sunrisers Hyderabad to the 2016 title, told ESPNCricinfo. тАЬWe already have evidence of that with the number of teams who have scored over 200, (it) is a record number of 200-plus scores of any IPL and we are not even close to the finish.тАЭ While the likes of greats Kohli and David Warner have struggled to meet the intensity, left-handed batsman Rinku has come into his own as a finisher this season. He raised the hitting stakes when he smashed five sixes in the last five balls to pull off a miracle chase for Kolkata last month. The tournament has witnessed six last-ball finishes this season and Mumbai batsman Nehal Wadhera pointed to the impact sub again. тАЬThe Impact Player rule also gives the batters a bit of freedom to play fearlessly as they know they have an extra batter in their wings,тАЭ Wadhera said. тАЬThe rule has also led to more close finishes in the IPL, which we love to watch.тАЭ

newsArray.title: PCB refuse to play Asia Cup outside Pakistan
newsArray.description: Pakistan Cricket Board (PCB) rejected the idea of playing Asia Cup outside Pakistan, as Sri Lanka Cricket Board had suggested to host the event in their country and letting Pakistan remain the official hosts. PCB suggested Asian Cricket Council (ACC) the hybrid model once again, in which it was offered that India can play their matches in UAE. Sri Lanka and Bangladesh do not have problem with the hybrid model but do not want to play matches in UAE due to hot weather. The board official told Samaa TV that PCB had written an email to the boards of Bangladesh and Sri Lanka that Asia Cup has been played in UAE in the past in the months of August and September as well. The honourary secretary of SLC Mohan De Silva has reportedly said that they have told ACC that they are against hybrid model and would be prepared to host Asia Cup in their country but nothing has been finalised yet. But Pakistan Cricket Board have stayed firm on their stance that they would boycott the event if it is held outside Pakistan.

newsArray.description: LONDON (Reuters) тАУ Skin cancer prevention should be a priority for cricketers and fans spending hours under the sun, England wicketkeeper Sam Billings has warned after suffering a scare last year. Billings underwent two operations last year to remove a malignant melanoma on his chest following a routine screening organised by his county Kent. The [тАж]
newsArray.content: FILE PHOTO: Cricket - Fifth Test - England v India - Edgbaston, Birmingham, Britain - July 1, 2022 England's Sam Billings in action Action Images via Reuters/Jason Cairnduff LONDON (Reuters) тАУ Skin cancer prevention should be a priority for cricketers and fans spending hours under the sun, England wicketkeeper Sam Billings has warned after suffering a scare last year. Billings underwent two operations last year to remove a malignant melanoma on his chest following a routine screening organised by his county Kent. The 31-year-old said his melanoma was caught just in time and that he almost missed the screening to attend a meeting. тАЬI had a melanoma that was 0.6mm (deep). The threshold of when it gets really serious is 0.7mm, so really close,тАЭ Billings told the Daily Telegraph. тАЬIf I had left that screening to go to the meeting, and waited until my next one six months down the line it could have been far, far more serious.тАЭ While searing heat and sunshine are regularly seen in Asia and Australia, Billings says conditions in Britain can be just as dangerous and that English players can be complacent. тАЬIтАЩm not just talking about the pro game. ItтАЩs club cricketers, people who watch the game,тАЭ he said. тАЬI played at LordтАЩs recently and the sun was out, even if it wasnтАЩt 25 degrees. It might only have been 18 but you can still get sunburnt. We treat it (applying suncream) like a bit of a chore, because the education around it isnтАЩt as good as in countries like Australia. тАЬIтАЩd like to see everyone in cricket working together: the sun is out, so letтАЩs protect ourselves.тАЭ

newsArray.title: Boult still wants to play for New Zealand at World Cup
keywords: Boult still wants to play for New Zealand at World Cup
creator: Reuters Reuters
newsArray.description: (Reuters) тАУ Seamer Trent Boult still wants to play for New Zealand at this yearтАЩs World Cup and tests next year despite giving up his central contract to allow him to spend more time with his family. The 33-year-old, who with Tim Southee has made up one of the worldтАЩs most feared pace attacks over [тАж]
newsArray.content: FILE PHOTO: Cricket - New Zealand Practice Session - Trent Bridge, Nottingham, Britain - June 9, 2022 New Zealand's Trent Boult during practice Action Images via Reuters/Andrew Boyers/File Photo (Reuters) тАУ Seamer Trent Boult still wants to play for New Zealand at this yearтАЩs World Cup and tests next year despite giving up his central contract to allow him to spend more time with his family. The 33-year-old, who with Tim Southee has made up one of the worldтАЩs most feared pace attacks over the last decade, has not played international cricket since negotiating a тАЬsignificantly reduced roleтАЭ with the Black Caps in August. тАЬIтАЩve still got that big desire to play for New Zealand,тАЭ Boult told Cricinfo in Jaipur, where he is playing for the Rajasthan Royals in the Indian Premier League (IPL). тАЬIt is what it is: IтАЩve made my decision. IтАЩve been lucky enough to have a 13-year career in the Black Cap and hey, IтАЩve still got a big desire to play in the World Cup as well. тАЬItтАЩs such a great tournament тАж one hundred percent, IтАЩve got that desire to be out there.тАЭ Boult was part of the squads that finished runners-up at the last two 50-overs World Cups and thought New Zealand would again be a force in India in October and November. тАЬWeтАЩre a great one-day side,тАЭ he added. тАЬWeтАЩve got some players that have travelled to India and experienced the conditions a lot, and thatтАЩs what it comes down to in World Cups. тАЬYou canтАЩt buy experience, and you canтАЩt replace players that have toured for however many years across these conditions.тАЭ Boult was snubbed for New ZealandтАЩs home test series against England earlier this year, despite the hosts losing a string of fast bowlers to injury and the first test taking place close to his Mount Maunganui home. тАЬIt felt bizarre,тАЭ he said. тАЬTest match cricket was on, a couple of kilometres down the road, and I wasnтАЩt part of it.тАЭ The pace spearhead said he hoped he had not played his last match for New Zealand in the longest format. тАЬThere are some big tests coming up next year. Australia and South Africa are due to travel to New Zealand. And test cricket is still my favourite format.тАЭ тАЬThey said that if I chose to move away from that contract, my time тАж would be limited and IтАЩm pretty sure theyтАЩve never had anyone play test cricket that isnтАЩt contracted тАУ so that probably makes it hard as well.тАЭ

newsArray.title: England cricketer Sam Billings reveals his battle with skin cancer
newsArray.description: England cricketer Sam Billings has revealed he underwent two operations to remove a malignant melanoma on his chest as he warned his fellow players about the risks of skin cancer.
newsArray.content: England cricketer Sam Billings has revealed he underwent two operations to remove a malignant melanoma on his chest as he warned his fellow players about the risks of skin cancer. Wicketkeeper Billings, 31, said his England team-mates were left shocked by his тАШgory and bloodyтАЩ six-inch scar and stitches when he removed his shirt in the changing rooms during last yearтАЩs white-ball tour of Australia. He admits he was fortunate to have the skin cancer diagnosed during a routine screening at his county, Kent, before it developed into anything worse. Billings recovered to play a full winter of cricket but is urging players at all levels of the game to make sure they apply suncream when they take the field. On that moment in the England dressing room, he told the Daily Telegraph: тАШI had completely forgotten it was there! But I still had my stitches in and it was pretty gory, still bloody and healing. I think the boys were pretty shocked. тАШIтАЩve been that classic Brit abroad. As a 22-year-old with fairer hair in Australia thinking it was worth going a bit red to end up brown. тАШAnd at home you see it all the time, it gets to 12 degrees and sunny, all the tops come off. I didnтАЩt think IтАЩd be the guy who got skin damage. I hope people see my story and think twice.тАЩ Billings almost skipped the skin cancer screening at Kent because there was a queue and he was running late for a meeting. It was only the intervention of the clubтАЩs head physio Dan George that persuaded the captain to hang around. It revealed a mole on his upper chest that needed to be removed. Billings was told he had a melanoma that was 0.6mm deep, with the threshold of 0.7mm being when things can really get serious, and was immediately refereed for an operation. тАШI could see inside my own chest, which wasnтАЩt very nice,тАЩ he said. тАШAt one point the anaesthetic didnтАЩt work well so I was in huge pain. тАШI never realised how much your chest affects everything else. Just moving my arm was extremely painful. Mentally it was definitely more challenging than physically.тАЩ In partnership with the Professional CricketersтАЩ Association and Lifejacket Skin Protection, Billings has warned club cricketers not to get sunburnt when they play. тАШWe treat it [applying suncream] like a bit of a chore because the education around it isnтАЩt as good as in countries like Australia,тАЩ he added. Billings isnтАЩt the first top-level sportsman to reveal they have suffered from skin cancer. The Germany and Bayern Munich goalkeeper Manuel Neuer revealed last year he required three operations to remove a tumour from his face. Tennis star Angelique Kerber has also suffered from the sun-induced skin condition hyperpigmentation. The lifelong condition, which can be easily treated, is caused by exposure to the sun and leads to spots or patches that look brown, black, grey, red or pink on the skin. (Daily Mail)

newsArray.title: 3 things we learnt about Zimbabwe A from day 1 of the 2nd four-dayer against the Shaheens
creator: 3-mob.com
newsArray.description: It was not good day for Zimbabwe A The post 3 things we learnt about Zimbabwe A from day 1 of the 2nd four-dayer against the Shaheens first appeared on Three Men On a Boat.
newsArray.content: Zimbabwe A had one good thing and a lot of bad things on a the first day of the Pakistan Shaheens in Mutare Sports Club. The visitors came into the match holding a 1-0 lead after winning the match in Kwekwe last week. The Shaheens won the toss and put Zimbabwe A. They were bowled out for what would have been a very disappointing 163 just after tea. The Shaheens are 115 for the loss of one wicket at stumps. Here are the three lessons we learnt Once seen as a white ball player, Tadiwanashe Marumani is showing that he has fight and grit, He scored 66 runs in a 110-run partnership with Dion Myers, which looked to have set the Zimbabweans for a good first innings score. He generally leftt well and punished the bad balls in an innings which had a strike rate of 66. What the Shaheens showed is that once one is in, you should get a big one. The Zimbabweans on the other hand seem to be comfortable with the half century and very rarely take it further. Three players had ducks meaning they added nothing to the total. The senior players in the team were absent. That Nyasha Mayavo was next highest with 17 is simply at odds with where Zimbabwe want to be. Or at least where they want to to go. The match resumes on day two at 9.15am. On this episode of the Clubhouse End Podcast, Larry Kwirirayi is joined by Stan Chioza to discuss Joylord GumbieтАЩs century against Pakistan Shaheens, Dion Myers, Selection, a quick buildup to the Qualifier, Kelis Ndhlovu and WomenтАЩs cricket development in Zimbabwe.

newsArray.title: Power-hitters raise the bar in new era of IPL run-fests
creator: Ariana News
newsArray.description: A marauding Faf du Plessis and emerging power-hitters including Rinku Singh have helped make team totals over 200 the new normal in this high-scoring edition of the Indian Premier League. The 38-year-old South African Du Plessis, captain of Royal Challengers Bangalore, leads the batting charts with 576 runs at a destructive strike rate of over [тАж] The post Power-hitters raise the bar in new era of IPL run-fests first appeared on Ariana News.
newsArray.content: The 38-year-old South African Du Plessis, captain of Royal Challengers Bangalore, leads the batting charts with 576 runs at a destructive strike rate of over 157 and 32 sixes. This season does not finish until the end of the month but it has already witnessed 30 innings totalling 200 or above. That happened on 18 occasions in the entire edition last year. Du Plessis hit 65 on Tuesday and forged a 120-run stand with Glenn Maxwell тАФ but opponents Mumbai Indians still reached the 200 target with 3.3 overs to spare, AFP reported. This season third-placed Mumbai have chased down three 200 or 200-plus totals with Suryakumar Yadav hitting half-centuries in all of them. тАЬI have no idea what a safe score is. The last four games we have seen excess of 200 has been scored,тАЭ said Mumbai skipper Rohit Sharma. тАЬMost of the teams are taking risks and it is coming off. тАЬThe batters are taking risks and 200-plus scores are being chased. тАЬThe mindset of the batters is to do something special for the team and it is coming off as well.тАЭ Players and pundits say there are a few reasons for the tall totals. IPL pitches are more batting friendly than before to encourage big-hitting and provide more entertainment. Former Australia batsman and ex-IPL coach Tom Moody says that the Kookaburra balls could have something to do with it because they are not swinging as much. The nature of Twenty20 cricket is also evolving, with a new breed of specialists. But the biggest factor behind the skyscraper scores in the IPL looks to be the new Impact Player rule. It allows a substitute and effectively adds an extra batsman or bowler to the team line-up. Lucknow Super Giants have led the high-rise war after they posted the second-highest team total since the IPL began in 2008. They made 257-5 in a 56-run victory last month against Punjab Kings, with West IndiesтАЩ Kyle Mayers and Australian all-rounder Marcus Stoinis smashing 11 boundaries each. Virat Kohli recently scored a 46-ball 55 in a losing cause for Bangalore and the superstar batsman was criticized for consuming too many deliveries. Moody called KohliтАЩs innings тАЬyesterdayтАЩs approach or last yearтАЩs approachтАЭ. тАЬNow we have an impact player, the game has changed,тАЭ the Australian, who took Sunrisers Hyderabad to the 2016 title, told ESPNCricinfo. тАЬWe already have evidence of that with the number of teams who have scored over 200, (it) is a record number of 200-plus scores of any IPL and we are not even close to the finish.тАЭ While the likes of greats Kohli and David Warner have struggled to meet the intensity, left-handed batsman Rinku has come into his own as a finisher this season. He raised the hitting stakes when he smashed five sixes in the last five balls to pull off a miracle chase for Kolkata last month. The tournament has witnessed six last-ball finishes this season and Mumbai batsman Nehal Wadhera pointed to the impact sub again. тАЬThe Impact Player rule also gives the batters a bit of freedom to play fearlessly as they know they have an extra batter in their wings,тАЭ Wadhera said. тАЬThe rule has also led to more close finishes in the IPL, which we love to watch.тАЭ

newsArray.title: PCB refuse to play Asia Cup outside Pakistan
newsArray.description: Pakistan Cricket Board (PCB) rejected the idea of playing Asia Cup outside Pakistan, as Sri Lanka Cricket Board had suggested to host the event in their country and letting Pakistan remain the official hosts. PCB suggested Asian Cricket Council (ACC) the hybrid model once again, in which it was offered that India can play their matches in UAE. Sri Lanka and Bangladesh do not have problem with the hybrid model but do not want to play matches in UAE due to hot weather. The board official told Samaa TV that PCB had written an email to the boards of Bangladesh and Sri Lanka that Asia Cup has been played in UAE in the past in the months of August and September as well. The honourary secretary of SLC Mohan De Silva has reportedly said that they have told ACC that they are against hybrid model and would be prepared to host Asia Cup in their country but nothing has been finalised yet. But Pakistan Cricket Board have stayed firm on their stance that they would boycott the event if it is held outside Pakistan.

newsArray.description: LONDON (Reuters) тАУ Skin cancer prevention should be a priority for cricketers and fans spending hours under the sun, England wicketkeeper Sam Billings has warned after suffering a scare last year. Billings underwent two operations last year to remove a malignant melanoma on his chest following a routine screening organised by his county Kent. The [тАж]
newsArray.content: FILE PHOTO: Cricket - Fifth Test - England v India - Edgbaston, Birmingham, Britain - July 1, 2022 England's Sam Billings in action Action Images via Reuters/Jason Cairnduff LONDON (Reuters) тАУ Skin cancer prevention should be a priority for cricketers and fans spending hours under the sun, England wicketkeeper Sam Billings has warned after suffering a scare last year. Billings underwent two operations last year to remove a malignant melanoma on his chest following a routine screening organised by his county Kent. The 31-year-old said his melanoma was caught just in time and that he almost missed the screening to attend a meeting. тАЬI had a melanoma that was 0.6mm (deep). The threshold of when it gets really serious is 0.7mm, so really close,тАЭ Billings told the Daily Telegraph. тАЬIf I had left that screening to go to the meeting, and waited until my next one six months down the line it could have been far, far more serious.тАЭ While searing heat and sunshine are regularly seen in Asia and Australia, Billings says conditions in Britain can be just as dangerous and that English players can be complacent. тАЬIтАЩm not just talking about the pro game. ItтАЩs club cricketers, people who watch the game,тАЭ he said. тАЬI played at LordтАЩs recently and the sun was out, even if it wasnтАЩt 25 degrees. It might only have been 18 but you can still get sunburnt. We treat it (applying suncream) like a bit of a chore, because the education around it isnтАЩt as good as in countries like Australia. тАЬIтАЩd like to see everyone in cricket working together: the sun is out, so letтАЩs protect ourselves.тАЭ
